values: Conduct a full Pre-Combat Check (PCC) and Pre-Combat Inspection (PCI) using the approved Marshalling Checklist.
Assign qualified inspectors (CO, 1SG, designated Inspectors).
Use a documented sign‑off sheet for each vehicle.
Re‑inspect any deficiencies before the final inspection window.
Perform PCC/PCI 30 minutes prior to CO/1SG inspection.
Utilize the printed checklist; record findings on the inspection sheet.
Correct deficiencies and re‑inspect within the allotted time.
CO, 1SG, Vehicle Crews, Designated Inspectors (VCs, PLs)

subtasks.hazard: Improper Load Securing (tie‑downs, load plan, bump plan)

values: Verify load plan and bump plan against the vehicle’s load chart.
Use approved tie‑down straps; ensure at least two points of redundancy.
Conduct a visual inspection of all cargo, rucksacks, and equipment before movement.
Re‑inspection at 0900 and 1300 to confirm integrity.
VCs lead cargo crews through the tie‑down SOP.
Inspector signs off on the load plan checklist.
Any non‑conforming load is re‑secured before departure.
Vehicle Commanders (VCs), Load NCO, Inspectors, Drivers
Confirm all required HAZMAT certifications are on personnel files.
Inspect for proper placards on each vehicle carrying hazardous material.
Store hazardous items in approved containers; seal and label correctly.
Include fire extinguisher and spill kit checks in the inspection.
RSO conducts a HAZMAT walkthrough with the HAZMAT NCO.
Document placard presence on the inspection sheet.
RSO, HAZMAT NCO, Vehicle Crews, Inspectors
Establish lane markings and speed limit of 15 km/h within the yard.
Employ ground guides at all intersections and tight turns.
Use hand‑and‑arm signals and radio deconfliction on designated channels.
Maintain a minimum 10 m spacing between moving vehicles.
Convoy brief includes lane assignments and guide positions.
Ground guides wear high‑visibility vests and use standard signals.
Ground Guides, Drivers, Convoy Leaders, Safety NCO
All vehicles equipped with functional night lights and NVG‑compatible headlights.
Conduct a night‑time safety brief covering NVG use and vehicle lighting.
Mark lane boundaries with reflective tape or low‑light markers.
Ground guides equipped with night‑vision devices.
Perform a short night‑time rehearsal of lane movements before the official completion time.

Confirm all radios, ATAK, and WICKR handles are uploaded to the unit SITREP before start.
Conduct a COMEX (communication exercise) at 0800 to verify HF, VHF, and data nets.
Establish a backup FM radio channel and a designated redundancy procedure.

Use a pre‑flight checklist that includes all required forms (DA Form 5987, DD‑518, SF‑91, Safety Cards, etc.).
Assign a paperwork NCO to verify each vehicle's dispatch book before SP.

subtasks.hazard: Fire Hazard (Inoperable Extinguishers or Fuel Leaks)

values: Inspect fire extinguishers for service date and pressure gauge.
Check for fuel leaks, CL‑III leaks, and ensure trailer parking brakes are OFF.
Include a brief fire‑suppression drill during the safety brief.
RSO conducts a hands‑on check of each extinguisher and records status.
RSO, Safety NCO, Vehicle Crews
Verify each driver possesses a valid USAREUR‑AF, Military, and/or ADR license as required.
Maintain a licence roster on the vehicle inspection board.
Any driver without proper licensing is prohibited from operating the vehicle.
OIC/NCOIC review licence copies during the pre‑movement inspection.
OIC, NCOIC, Driver NCO

ai_assessment.rationale: The generated hazards and mitigations are based on common risks identified in prior DRAW examples for marshalling and convoy operations. While the controls address the majority of identified threats, load‑securing, HAZMAT handling, night visibility, and communications are complex areas that often depend on specific unit SOPs, equipment condition, and real‑time environmental factors. Human verification is recommended to ensure that the checklist items align with unit‑specific procedures and that all required certifications and equipment are current.
